title: MOVIES: Were ‘Back to the Future’ predictions accurate?
text:
By PETER LARSEN, TIMOTHY GUY AND VANESSA FRANKO / STAFF WRITERS
Published: Oct. 20, 2015 Updated: 11:27 p.m. MOVIES: Were ‘Back to the Future’ predictions accurate? Print Photo Share Pin It More Galleries ADVERTISEMENT Related article » Fact/fiction Inventions/fads from the film that came true: Video phones, low-noise cars (hybrids), camera-enabled drones, facial-recognition systems, flat-panel TVs, smart TVs, split-screen TV viewing, thumbprint locks, computerized glasses, online banking, cash-free payments.
Things we're still waiting on: Sleep-inducing alpha-rhythm generators, barcode auto license plates, self-adjusting/self-drying clothing, suspended-animation kennels, mobile trashcans, chiropractic hoverbelts.
Things that came – and went already: Home fax machines, high-tech payphones, CD-ROMS and LaserDiscs (well, they're already in the trash in the movie).
Are the movies in your future? There are, of course, many good reasons to stay at home on the couch, not least of them the fact that a 30th anniversary box set of all three movies and a ton of bonus features came out Tuesday.
But why not share the day or the rest of the week with fellow fans? Here are some Inland Southern California theaters where you can see marathons of all three movies today, with some starting at 4:29 p.m. – the exact time when Marty and Doc travel to Oct. 21, 2015.
AMC Theatres: Tyler Galleria 16 in Riverside and Ontario Mills 30 at 4:29 p.m. $6.29, amctheatres.com
Regal Cinemas: Riverside Plaza Stadium 16, Edwards Eastvale Gateway Stadium 14, Edwards Ontario Palace Stadium 22, San Bernardino Stadium 14, Edwards Corona Crossings Stadium 18, Hemet Cinema 12, San Jacinto Metro 12 and Edwards Temecula Stadium 15, at 5 p.m., prices vary by theater, regmovies.com
Cinemark: Chino Movies 8, Rancho Mirage River 15 and Apple Valley 12 at 4:29 p.m. for $9, cinemark.com
Just "II": Harkins Theatres locations in Chino Hills and Moreno Valley will screen "Back to the Future II" at 7 p.m. for $5, harkinstheatres.com
Great Scott! It’s here!
Oct. 21, 2015: The date on which Michael J. Fox as Marty McFly and Christopher Lloyd as Doc Brown landed after time traveling 30 years into the future in the second installment of the “Back to the Future” film trilogy.
Or you can look at it as the date from which the filmmakers peered at the end of the ’80s and tried to imagine what the world of today – this very day – would be like.
Here, let’s check real quick and see how they did.
Take a moment and look up in the sky. See any flying cars?
Yeah, that didn’t quite pan out.
Now pick up your phone and talk to a friend on FaceTime or Skype.
Video calls! Nailed it!
As movie theaters prepare to show all three movies today and as anybody lucky enough to own a DeLorean, the gull-winged car in which Doc built his time machine, gets mobbed everywhere they go, we went in search of the facts, the fictions, the lure and the legend.
Buckle your seat belts.
PREDICTING THE FUTURE?

TIME MACHINE
In the movie: Marty travels to the past and the future in a DeLorean outfitted by his scientist pal Doc with a flux capacitor that can navigate the circuits of time.
In reality: Don’t hold your breath. And DeLoreans aren’t even rolling off assembly lines anymore, either.
Expert says: Time travel is still, as far as anyone today knows, fantasy. “Fundamentally, it’s that no one has any ideas to get around the idea,” said Ward Beyermann, associate professor of physics and astronomy at UC Riverside. “Predicting the future is dangerous. No one knows.”

TRASH FOR FUEL
In the movie: The Doc tosses trash into the Mr. Fusion Home Energy Reactor to power the DeLorean time machine.
In reality: Matter such as potatoes and frying oils have been turned into biodiesel fuel. As for widespread use, it will likely arrive in the next 10 to 15 years, according to Char Miller, environmental analysis professor at Pomona College in Claremont.
Expert says: “Even 30 years ago,” Miller said, “the crazy Doc Brown was telling us that everyday objects like banana peels and beer cans can be turned into energy. And it’s taken us that long to realize that landfills are filled with sources of energy.”

FLYING CARS
In the movie: The DeLorean can soar through time – and when it arrives in the future, just about everyone scoots around that way. Who needs the 91 freeway when you can rise above it all?
In reality: While Jetsons-style skycars won’t be an alternative to a jammed freeway anytime soon, a number of companies are working on prototypes.
Expert says: “It’s difficult to imagine the impact of flying cars,” said UCR’s Beyermann. “You would need a device that can take off, land and fly in this environment. And it has to be quiet and safe. We have enough trouble traveling in two dimensions without throwing in a third.”

SELF-TYING SHOES
In the movie: When Marty arrives in Hill Valley on Oct. 21, 2015, his scientist pal Doc Brown hands him a pair of shoes. After pulling them on, they automatically conform to his feet and are “laced up.”
In reality: Nike has a patent for self-lacing shoes and auctioned 1,500 pairs for charity in 2011. But, no, they haven’t landed at the mall yet.
Expert says: The fashion industry is buzzing about the possibility. Nike and Kanye West are already starting to use more futuristic textiles in footwear. “I think the self-lacing shoes is going to be something” real, said Erica Moreno, educational outreach coordinator for Porcelynne’s Fabric Boutique & Design Institute in Redlands.

HOVERBOARDS
In the movie: Marty is totally stoked to find that skateboards have shed their wheels and can race along a foot above the surface (but not, spoiler alert, above water).
In reality: Our ruling here is fiction, though in recent years a few companies have demonstrated prototypes of boards that “hover” using magnetic levitation, though those only work over metallic surfaces so they’re more gimmick than reality. Luxury car manufacturer Lexus made a splash earlier this year with a video showing off its hoverboard, which uses magnetic fields and superconductors.
Expert says: “For the record, Lexus isn’t developing a hoverboard or flying car for consumer use but there are agencies that are exploring this for a sellable consumer item,” Lexus spokesman Maurice Durand wrote in an email.

HOLOGRAM BILLBOARD
In the movie: A 3D “Jaws 19” hologram dives from a movie marquee to the street where Marty is standing in broad daylight, scaring the wholly shark out of him.
In reality: Holograms are already here in big-scale productions. A lifelike hologram of the late Tupac Shakur joined Snoop Dogg and Dr. Dre onstage at the 2012 Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival. A year later, Rock the Bells in San Bernardino brought both Eazy-E and ODB to the stage in hologram form.
Expert says: The 3D billboards have made the rounds at trade shows, but the technology hasn’t reached large outdoor displays yet, said Robert Bledsoe √ , director of marketing for Ontario-based LED display manufacturer Optec Displays.

PEPSI PERFECT
In the movie: When Marty stops into Cafe ’80s, he sees computer-generated celebrities – Michael Jackson, Ronald Reagan and, presumably, Ayatollah Khomeini for some strange reason – serving as video waiters. He orders a drink and up pops a Pepsi Perfect.
In reality: The product appears onscreen in a fancy curved bottled that never existed – until today, when Pepsi is selling 6,500 of them for $20.15 each. That price will surely rise in the immediate future to something as ridiculous as the hat the bully Griff is wearing when he walks into the cafe a minute later. So it’s a fact, if short-lived.
Expert says: “Pepsi fans asked, and we heard them loud and clear,” said Lou Arbetter, senior director of marketing for PepsiCo, in a present-day news release. Want to pay $20 for a soda? Visit pepsi.com for future opportunities.

NEW NEWS
In the movie: Well, USA Today in paper form is still a fact, duh, but what we’re interested in is the news on its front page for Oct. 22, 2015, the edition Doc shows Marty once they land in Hill Valley of the future.
In reality: Here’s a sampling of headlines and our verdict:
“Marshall runs 3-minute mile.” Fiction. Hicham El Guerrouj’s world record is a distant 3:43.13.
“Washington prepares for Queen Diana’s visit.” Sadly fiction. Princess Diana died in a car crash in 1997, but even if she’d lived Queen Elizabeth still hasn’t stepped down from her throne.
“President says she’s tired.” Fiction, for now, though Democrat Hillary Clinton and Republican Carly Fiorina are in the race for next year’s election.
“Cubs sweep series in 5.” Also fiction for now, though this is the one that’s got the sports world abuzz. The hapless Cubs are actually alive in the postseason for the first time in many years, though after dropping the first three games of their National League Championship Series to the New York Mets they need to get it together if they’re to make the World Series, much less win one for the first time in 107 years.
Expert says: You can’t “sweep in 5” anyway in our current best-of-seven-style series, according to, well, baseball fans.
